title: Leeds 1-0 Sheffield Weds: Chris Wood nets decisive strike at Elland Road - 5 things we learned
text:
Chris Wood celebrates his winning goal for Leeds against Sheffield Wednesday (Photo: EMPICS Sport) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Leeds United came out on top in a closely-fought Yorkshire Derby to strengthen their Championship play-off push. 
Chris Wood’s 20th league goal of the season was the difference between the two sides in a game which also saw Sheffield Wednesday miss a second-half penalty. 
The home side started the better side and were deservedly ahead midway through the first half when striker Wood calmly slotted home Gaetano Berardi’s right-wing cross from close range on 24 minutes. 
The Owls came more into the game closer to the break and both Fernando Forestieri and Jordan Rhodes blazed over from inside the area. 
Wood went close to doubling the lead shortly after the restart when he curled an effort just wide of Keiren Westwood’s right-hand post before the visitors were gifted a golden chance to draw level on 54 minutes from the penalty spot. Pablo Hernandez of Leeds United in action (Photo: Nathan Stirk) 
Souleymane Doukara was guilty of pulling down Sam Hutchinson in the area but Jordan Rhodes’s spot-kick was tipped on to the post by Robert Green. 
Here are the five things we learned from the match: Wood was too hot to handle 
Leeds United front man Chris Wood is enjoying one of the best seasons of his career and his performance here today highlighted why he is one of the division’s hottest strikers. 
The New Zealander tucked home his 20th league goal of the season and 23rd in all competitions from close range with ice-cold composure to break the deadlock. 
His goals have been instrumental in propelling Gary Monk’s men into the top six and he’s accountable for almost half of their league tally this season. Pontus Jansson of Leeds United tackles Fernando Forestieri (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
However, it’s not just his goals that make him so important for Leeds. His all-round play and strength caused centre half Vincent Sasso all manner of problems and even led to the defender being booked in the first half after he turned him on the halfway line. 
If Leeds are to realise their ambition this season, Wood’s form in the final 13 games is going to be crucial. Both teams look odds-on for a top six finish 
There may be 12 games still to go but it would take an almighty collapse by one of these two teams for them not to finish in the top six. 
Under Gary Monk, Leeds are enjoying their best season since dropping out of the Premier League 13 years ago and have been a staple fixture in the top six. Kyle Bartley of Leeds United gestures (Photo: Nathan Stirk) 
The Owls have been here before, having reached the play-off final last season and have the experience of coping with the pressure of a Championship run-in. Home is where the heart is for Leeds 
Elland Road for a long time in recent years has not been the fortress it once was in English football but Monk has changed that this season. 
Leeds have one of the best home records in the division and have lost just two of their last 15 league games on home soil. 
There is now a real belief that this sleeping giant is slowly awakening after more than a decade outside the top flight. Robert Green of Leeds United saves Jordan Rhodes of Sheffield Wednesday's penalty (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
And with an incredible 45,093 fans inside the ground for a lunchtime kick-off, this famous old stadium is once again becoming the tough place it once was to visit. Strong case for the defence 
While striker Chris Wood will take the plaudits for notching his milestone goal, Leeds had their defensive unit and keeper Robert Green to thank for the victory. 
The former England keeper produced a superb stop, diving low to his left, to deny Jordan Rhodes from the penalty spot nine minutes after the restart. 
However, the whole back four of Luke Ayling, Kyle Bartley, Pontus Jansson and Gaetano Berardi were outstanding in the second half as The Owls pushed for an equaliser. 
Make no mistake, the foundations for victory were laid at the back. Wednesday fire power the envy of most teams 
Wednesday may be the lowest scorers of all the teams in the top six but they have a strike force that will be the envy of many managers in the division. Fernando Forestieri of Sheffield Wednesday attempts an over-head kick (Photo: Nathan Stirk) 
Striker Jordan Rhodes and Fernando Forestieri began the day up front for Carlos Carvalhal’s team and would be first choice in almost any team in the division. 
However, in such a demanding league, strength in depth is crucial and Carvalhal had that in abundance with former Sunderland man Steven Fletcher and January signing Sam Winnall on the bench. 
Add Gary Hooper to that list and it’s easy to see why they are not short of attacking options. 
Carvalhal will need all of these players in the run-in if the Owls are to try and go one better than last season. 
Wednesday were much better after the break but could not find an equaliser after stout defending from the hosts. Player ratings
